title: Yann Tiersen
text:
{{Short description|French musician and composer (born 1970)}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2020}}
{{Infobox musical artist
| name             = Yann Tiersen
| image            = File:Yann Tiersen 1.jpg
| caption          = Tiersen in 2007
| background       = solo_singer
| birth_name       = Yann Pierre Tiersen
| alias            =
| birth_date       = {{Birth date and age|1970|6|23|df=y}}
| birth_place      = [[Brest, France|Brest]], [[Brittany]], [[France]]
| instrument       = [[Piano]], [[violin]], [[piano accordion]], [[electric guitar]], [[toy piano]], [[voice]], and various others
| genre            = [[Minimalist music|Minimal]], [[Avant-garde music|avant-garde]], [[post-rock]], [[folktronica]], {{nowrap|[[bal-musette]]}}

| label            = Sine Terra Firma, [[Ici, d'ailleurs...]], [[EMI Records|EMI]], [[Virgin Records|Virgin]], [[Mute Records|Mute]], [[ANTI-]]
| associated_acts  = [[Claire Pichet]], [[Dominique A]], [[Françoiz Breut]], [[Natacha Régnier]], [[Shannon Wright]], [[Christine Ott]]
| website          = {{URL|www.yanntiersen.com|www.yanntiersen.com}}

'''Yann Tiersen''' (born 23 June 1970) is a [[Bretons | Breton]] [[musician]] and [[composer]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Salarich |first=Albert |others=Jennifer O'Boyle (trans.) |title=Yann Tiersen: not only about Amelie |url=http://www.cafebabel.co.uk/article/yann-tiersen-not-only-about-amelie.html |website=Cafebabel.com |date=6 April 2007 |url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141218211927/http://www.cafebabel.co.uk/article/yann-tiersen-not-only-about-amelie.html|archive-date=18 December 2014}}</ref><ref name="MusicOMH-2002">{{cite web |last=Hubbard |first=Michael |url=http://www.musicomh.com/features/interviews/interview-yann-tiersen |title=Interview: Yann Tiersen |work=Features |publisher=[[MusicOMH]] |year=2002 }}</ref> His musical career is split between studio recordings, music collaborations and film soundtracks songwriting. His music incorporates a large variety of classical and contemporary instruments, primarily the [[electric guitar]], the [[piano]], [[synthesisers]] and the [[violin]], but also instruments such as the [[melodica]], [[xylophone]], [[toy piano]], [[harpsichord]], [[piano accordion]] or even [[typewriter]].

Tiersen is often mistaken for a soundtrack composer; as he is quoted about himself: "I'm not a composer and I really don't have a classical background,"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.archive.thegauntlet.ca/story/more-just-couple-soundtracks |title=More than just a couple of soundtracks |first=Andrea |last=Rojas |work=Entertainment |publisher=[[Gauntlet (newspaper)|The Gauntlet]] |date=17 February 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160108180833/http://www.archive.thegauntlet.ca/story/more-just-couple-soundtracks |archive-date=8 January 2016 }}</ref> but his real focus is on touring and recording studio albums, which are often used for film soundtracks. Tracks taken from his first three studio albums were used for the soundtrack of the 2001 French film ''[[Amélie]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yanntiersen.com/albums |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927112229/http://www.yanntiersen.com/albums |url-status=dead |archive-date=27 September 2011 |title=Albums |publisher=Yann Tiersen Official Website }}</ref>

==Biography and career==
===The early years: 1970–1992===
Tiersen was born in 1970 in [[Brest, France|Brest]], in the department of [[Finistère]], part of [[Brittany]] in northwestern France, into a French family of [[Belgian people|Belgian]] and [[Norwegians|Norwegian]] origins.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://www.lagazettedeberlin.de/6137.html |title=Yann Tiersen : " La solution est globale : la révolution " |language=fr |trans-title=Yann Tiersen: "The Solution Is Global: The Revolution" |journal=La Gazette de Berlin |issue=35 |year=2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100907004922/http://www.lagazettedeberlin.de/6137.html |archive-date=7 September 2010 }}</ref> He started learning to play the [[piano]] at the age of four, the [[violin]] at the age of six, and received classical training at several musical academies, including those in [[Rennes]], [[Nantes]], and [[Boulogne-sur-Mer]].<ref name="e2">{{cite web |url=http://everything2.com/index.pl?node=Yann+Tiersen |title=Yann Tiersen |website=Everything2.com }}</ref> In the early 1980s, he was influenced as a teenager by the [[punk subculture]], and bands like [[The Stooges]] and [[Joy Division]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Michael |last=Hubbard |title=Composer Tiersen serenades Amelie |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/1839313.stm |work=Entertainment |publisher=BBC News |date=24 February 2002 |access-date=5 June 2009}}</ref> When he was 13, he broke his violin, bought an [[electric guitar]], and formed a [[rock band]]. Tiersen was living in [[Rennes]] back then, home to the three-day music festival [[Rencontres Trans Musicales]], which is held annually in December. That gave him the opportunity to see acts like [[Nirvana (band)|Nirvana]], [[Einstürzende Neubauten]], [[Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds]], [[The Cramps]], [[Television (band)|Television]], and [[Suicide (band)|Suicide]]. A few years later, when his band parted, Tiersen bought a cheap [[Mixing console|mixing desk]], an [[8-track tape|8-track]] [[reel-to-reel audio tape recording|reel-to-reel tape recorder]], and started recording music on his own with a [[synthesiser]], a [[Sampler (musical instrument)|sampler]], and a [[drum machine]].<ref name="ATP-YT" />

===Debut and national acclaim: 1993–2000===
{{Main|La Valse des monstres|Rue des cascades|Le Phare}}
{{Quote box
 |width   = 234px
 |align   = right
 |salign  = right
 |quote   = Let’s live in an enormous world of sound we can use randomly, with no rules at all. Let’s play with sound, forget all knowledge and instrumental skills, and just use instinct — the same way punk did.
 |source  = —Yann Tiersen<ref name="ATP-YT" />
}}
Before releasing [[film score]]s under his own name, Tiersen recorded background music for a number of plays and short films. During the summer of 1993, Tiersen stayed in his apartment with an [[electric guitar]], a [[violin]] and a [[piano accordion]], recording music on his own; he was guided by what he calls "a musical anarchic vision". By the end of the summer, Tiersen had recorded over forty tracks, which would most be used later on for his first two albums. Tiersen's debut album, ''[[La Valse des monstres]]'', limited to 1,000 copies, was first released in June 1995 by [[independent record label]] Sine Terra Firma, and then reissued by [[Nancy, France|Nancy]]-based record label [[Ici, d'ailleurs...|Ici d'ailleurs]] in 1998 as the second album of its catalogue.<ref name="am-lvdm">{{AllMusic|class=album|id=r384473|label=''La Valse des Monstres''}}</ref> The 17-track-album was inspired by and written for the theatrical adaptations of [[Tod Browning]]'s 1932 cult classic ''[[Freaks (1932 film)|Freaks]]'', and [[Yukio Mishima]]'s 1955 version of [[Noh]] play ''[[Aya no Tsuzumi|The Damask Drum]]''.<ref>{{Cite book |title=Five modern nō plays |last=Mishima |first=Yukio |author-link=Yukio Mishima |year=1967 |publisher=Charles E. Tuttle |location=Tokyo |isbn=0804813809 |oclc=1836711 |quote=translated from the Japanese by Donald Keene. |url-access=registration |url=https://archive.org/details/fivemodernnoplay00mish }}</ref> In April 1996, one year later, he released ''[[Rue des cascades]]'', a collection of short pieces recorded with a [[toy piano]], a [[harpsichord]], a [[violin]], a [[piano accordion]], and a [[mandolin]].<ref name="am-rdc">{{AllMusic|class=album|id=r468432|label=''Rue Des Cascades''}}</ref> The title track, sung by French solo singer [[Claire Pichet]], was used the following year for the [[Palme d'Or]] nominated [[cinema of France|French]] [[Drama (film and television)|drama film]] ''[[The Dreamlife of Angels]]'',<ref name="festival-cannes.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/archives/ficheFilm/id/4905/year/1998.html |title=Festival de Cannes: The Dreamlife of Angels |access-date=1 October 2009 |website=Festival-cannes.com |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110820003730/http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/archives/ficheFilm/id/4905/year/1998.html |archive-date=20 August 2011 }}</ref> and several tracks received greater exposure when they were featured on the [[Jean-Pierre Jeunet]]'s film ''[[Amélie]]'', five years later.<ref name="ATP-YT" /> Tiersen usually plays most of the music instruments himself  during both studio recording sessions and his live sets; he has won theatrical appeal as a one-man show and was invited to play, among others, at the 1996 edition of the [[Festival d'Avignon|Avignon Festival]], the oldest live arts festival in France.<ref name="am-yt-bio">{{cite web |last=Phares |first=Heather |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/yann-tiersen-mn0000588745/biography |title=Yann Tiersen – Biography |website=[[AllMusic]]}}</ref>

{{Quote box
 |width   = 234px
 |align   = right
 |salign  = right
 |quote   = I was amazed with the way the lighthouse rays revealed some hidden details of the land, how we can rediscover something we have in front of us everyday, only thanks to a light pointing at it.
 |source  = —Yann Tiersen<ref name="ATP-YT" />
}}
Tiersen rose to domestic fame upon the release of his third studio album, ''[[Le Phare]]'' (''The Lighthouse'') in 1998.  The album was recorded in self-imposed seclusion on the isle of [[Ushant]] ({{Lang-br|Enez Eusa}}, {{Lang-fr|link=no|Ouessant}}) at the end of the [[English Channel]] which marks the most north-western point of territorial France. Tiersen spent two months there, living in a rented house. At night-time, he would watch the [[Phare du Creach]], one of the most powerful lighthouses in the world, and was fascinated by the stunning scenery repeated every night. ''Le Phare'', which featured [[Claire Pichet]], French singer and songwriter [[Dominique A]], and Belgian drummer and percussionist Sacha Toorop,<ref name="am-lp">{{AllMusic|class=album|id=R468433|label=''Le Phare''}}</ref> sold over 160,000 copies, confirming Tiersen's status as one of the most innovative artists of his generation and commencing a run of successful albums.<ref name="ATP-YT" /> Three songs from this album, "La Dispute", "La Noyée" and "Sur le fil" were later featured on the 2001 soundtrack ''[[Amélie (soundtrack)|Amélie]]'', while  "L'Homme aux bras ballants", written and composed by [[Dominique A]], was also featured on Laurent Gorgiard's 1997 short animation soundtrack of the same name. Its single "Monochrome", sung by [[Dominique A]], was a radio hit and propelled the album into the charts. ''[[Le Phare]]'' was his first album to climb to number 50 in the [[Syndicat National de l'Édition Phonographique|French Albums Chart]].<ref name="charts-fra" />

During that period, Tiersen provided a new arrangement and played [[Strings (music)|strings]], [[vibraphone]], [[Bell (instrument)|bell]], the mandolin, the [[electric guitar]] and [[bass guitar]] for the song "À ton étoile"  by French rock band [[Noir Désir]] which was featured on their 1998 [[remix album]] ''One Trip/One Noise''{{citation needed|date=November 2017}}. He recorded songs for the soundtrack of several films, including the award-winning and multi-nominated film ''[[The Dreamlife of Angels]]'' ({{Lang-fr|link=no|La Vie rêvée des anges}}) (1998),<ref name="festival-cannes.com" /><ref name="ac-1999">{{cite web |url=http://www.academie-cinema.org/ceremonie/palmares.html?annee=1999 |title=Palmarès 1999 – 24 ème cérémonie des César |language=fr |trans-title=Awards 1999 – 24th César Ceremony |publisher=Académie des César }}</ref> [[André Téchiné]]'s ''[[Alice et Martin]]'' (1998) and Christine Carrière's ''Qui plume la lune?'' (1999). Tiersen also recorded ''Bästard ~ Yann Tiersen'', a three-track-extended-play released in 1998 in collaboration with French [[electronic rock]] band Bästard, and his first live album, ''[[Black Session: Yann Tiersen]]''. The live album was recorded on 2 December 1998 as he played the opening act of the [[Rencontres Trans Musicales]] in the Salle Serreau at the [[Théâtre National de Bretagne]] in [[Rennes]], for the ''C'est Lenoir'' French broadcast show on the public radio station [[France Inter]]. The album features the chamber pop group [[The Divine Comedy (band)|The Divine Comedy]] fronted by Northern Irish singer and songwriter [[Neil Hannon]], the French rock band [[Noir Désir]] with singer and songwriter [[Bertrand Cantat]], singer and illustrator [[Françoiz Breut]], French rock band The Married Monk (Christian Quermalet, Philippe Lebruman, Etienne Jaumet, Nicolas Courret), French folk rock group [[Les Têtes Raides]] (Christian Olivier, Grègoire Simon, Pascal Olivier, Anne-Gaëlle Bisquay, Serge Bégout, Jean-Luc Millot, and Edith Bégou), the [[string quartet]] Quatuor à cordes, guitarist and composer Olivier Mellano, and author [[Mathieu Boogaerts]], as well as his usual collaborators and friends, Claire Pichet and Dominique A. The album was recorded by France International, mastered by [[Radio France]], and released in CD format one year later on 2 November 1999.{{citation needed|date=November 2017}}

In 1999, Tiersen together with The Married Monk, Claire Pichet, and Olivier Mellano released his <!--???fourth studio???-->first collaboration album, ''[[Tout est calme]]''. The 26 minutes, 10 tracks mini album peaked at number 45 on the French Albums Chart.<ref name="charts-fra" /> The album produced one single, "Les Grandes marées", and Tiersen also featured on The Divine Comedy's single "[[Gin Soaked Boy]]" released on that same year, on three tracks for Françoiz Breut's second studio album ''[[Vingt à Trente Mille Jours]]'' (English: Twenty to Thirty Thousand Days), and on Têtes Raides' ''Gratte-poil'', both released in 2000.

===''Amélie'' and global recognition: 2001–2009===
{{Main|Amélie (soundtrack)|L'Absente|Les Retrouvailles}}
{{Quote box
 |width   = 234px
 |align   = right
 |salign  = right
 |quote   = The hard part was making a selection, because all his tracks worked with the film's images!
 |source  = —[[Jean-Pierre Jeunet]]<ref name="ucf-JPJ" />
}}
Tiersen remained relatively unknown outside France until the release of his [[Amélie (soundtrack)|score]] for the acclaimed film ''[[Amélie]]'' (Original French title: ''Le Fabuleux Destin d'Amélie Poulain'', English: ''The Fabulous Destiny of Amélie Poulain'') in 2001. French film director [[Jean-Pierre Jeunet]] had something else in mind for the film score, but one day one of his production assistants put on a CD of Tiersen, and the director found it absolutely superb. Jeunet bought all of Tiersen's albums, and then contacted him to see if the [[Breton people|Breton]] composer was interested in writing the film score for ''Amélie''. In two weeks, Tiersen composed nineteen pieces for the film and also allowed the production to take anything they wanted from his other records.<ref name="ucf-JPJ">{{cite web |url=http://www.urbancinefile.com.au/home/view.asp?a=5593&s=Interviews |title=JEUNET, JEAN-PIERRE: FABULOUS DESTINY OF AMÉLIE |date=13 December 2001 |publisher=Urban Cinefile }}</ref> ''Amélie'' received great critical acclaim and was a box-office success. The film went on to win the Best Film award at the [[European Film Awards]], four [[César Award]]s, including [[César Award for Best Film|Best Film]] and [[César Award for Best Director|Best Director]], two [[55th British Academy Film Awards|BAFTA Awards]], including Best Original Screenplay, and was nominated for five [[Academy Award]]s. The soundtrack was a mixture of both new and previously released material, and Tiersen was also the recipient of the [[César Award]] for [[César Award for Best Music Written for a Film|Best Music Written for a Film]], and of the [[World Soundtrack Academy]] award. The soundtrack album charted in many countries, including the number one position on the [[Syndicat National de l'Édition Phonographique|French Albums Chart]].<ref name="MusicOMH-2002" /><ref>{{cite web |first=Steffen |last=Hung |url=http://lescharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Soundtrack+%2F+Yann+Tiersen&titel=Le+fabuleux+destin+d%27Am%E9lie+Poulain&cat=a |title=Soundtrack / Yann Tiersen – Le fabuleux destin d'Amélie Poulain |website=Lescharts.com |access-date=4 May 2012 }}</ref>

While he was writing the film score for ''Amélie'', Tiersen was also preparing his fifth studio album ''[[L'Absente]]''.<ref name="MusicOMH-2002" /> The album was characterized by several contributions including 35-member Ensemble Orchestral Synaxis conducted by Guillaume Bourgogne, viola player Bertrand Lambert, violinists Yann Bisquay and Sophie Naboulay, [[Natacha Régnier]], and saxophonist Grégoire Simon, and long-time collaborators Dominique A, [[Christine Ott]], [[Lisa Germano]], Neil Hannon, Têtes Raides, Christian Quermalet, Marc Sens, and Sacha Toorop.<ref name="am-la">{{AllMusic|class=album|id=r537853|label=''L'Absente''}}</ref> The album, which was released on 5 June 2001 through [[EMI]] France, was preceded by two promotional singles for "A quai" and "Bagatelle" respectively. Tiersen provided strings and vibraphone to two tracks, "Roma Amor" and "Holidays", featured on  ''R/O/C/K/Y'', the third studio album by The Married Monk.

At this time he was married to Belgian actress [[Natacha Régnier]], co-star of ''The Dreamlife of Angels''. Régnier became a singer and Tiersen wrote three songs for her including his arrangement of [[Georges Brassens]]' "Le Parapluie", a song featured on the tribute album ''Les Oiseaux de passage'', released in 2001. That same year they toured in France and abroad. They have a daughter, Lise, born in 2002, but Tiersen and Régnier have since divorced.<ref name="L-Lsdla">{{Cite journal |last=de Baecque |first=Antoine |date=10 November 2004 |title=Le saut de l'ange |language=fr |trans-title=The Jump of the Angel |journal=[[Libération]] |url=http://www.liberation.fr/portrait/0101508306-le-saut-de-l-ange }}</ref> In this period, Tiersen also took his music out around the world, playing shows with a full orchestra and an amplified string quartet.<ref name="ATP-YT" /> From 15 to 17 February 2002, Tiersen with many of the collaborators who participated in the recording sessions for ''L'Absente'' plus Claire Pichet, violinists Nicolas Stevens and Renaud Lhoest, bassist Jean-François Assy, viola player Olivier Tilkin, and [[uilleann pipes]], [[bagpipes]], and [[low whistle]] player Ronan Le Bars, performed live at the [[Cité de la Musique]] (''City of Music'') in Paris. Part of these three concerts went on to form Tiersen's second live album ''[[C'était ici]]'' (''It Was Here''), which was released through EMI France on 30 September 2002.<ref name="ma-cei">{{AllMusic |class=album |id=r642682 |label=''C'Était Ici'' }}</ref>

Tiersen's skills as a composer of film scores were much in demand, and the soundtrack for ''Amélie'' was soon followed by the [[Good Bye Lenin! (soundtrack)|film score]] for ''[[Good Bye, Lenin!]]'', a 2003 German [[Tragicomedy]] film directed by [[Wolfgang Becker (director, born 1954)|Wolfgang Becker]].<ref name="ATP-YT" /> The film was both a commercial and a critical success and won several awards including the [[César Award for Best Film from the European Union]], Best Film at the [[European Film Awards]], the [[Deutscher Filmpreis|German Film Awards]] for Outstanding Film, Best European Film at the [[Goya Awards]], Best Foreign Language Film for the [[London Film Critics' Circle]], and it was also listed in the ''[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]]'' magazine 2010's list of "The 100 Best Films of World Cinema".<ref>{{cite web |title=The 100 Best Films Of World Cinema |url=http://www.empireonline.com/features/100-greatest-world-cinema-films/default.asp?film=91 |work=[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]]}}</ref> Tiersen was the recipient of the German Film Awards for Outstanding Music. On 15 November 2003, Tiersen with [[Stuart A. Staples]], the lead singer of indie band [[Tindersticks]], actress and singer [[Jane Birkin]], singer and songwriter [[Miossec|Christophe Miossec]], and Dominique A released ''3 titres inédits au profit de la FIDH'' (''3 New Tracks for the Benefit of FIDH''), a three-track CD that was part of the ''On Aime, On Aide'' benefit collection for raising funds for the [[International Federation for Human Rights]] (FIDH).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://musique.fnac.com/a1490684/Yann-Tiersen-3-titres-inedits-au-profit-de-la-FIDH-On-aime-on-aide-CD-single |title=3 titres inédits au profit de la FIDH – On aime, on aide |website=Fnac.com }}</ref>

[[File:Yann Tiersen 6.jpg|thumb|alt=A photo showing Yann Tiersen (on the left) and Christophe Miossec (on the right) live in concert at Cabaret Vauban, Brest, France, on 6 February 2005.|Yann Tiersen (left) and [[Miossec|Christophe Miossec]] (right) at Cabaret Vauban, Brest, France, 6 February 2005.]]
Tiersen's list of collaborators continued to grow album after album and in October 2004 he released ''[[Yann Tiersen & Shannon Wright]]'', a collaboration album with American singer-songwriter [[Shannon Wright]], and, in the same year, he is featured on [[The Divine Comedy (band)|The Divine Comedy]]'s album ''[[Absent Friends (The Divine Comedy album)|Absent Friends]]''. In 2005, Tiersen released his fifth studio album ''[[Les Retrouvailles]]''. The album features several collaborators including the Orchestre National de Paris, singers Elizabeth Fraser, Jane Birkin, Stuart A. Staples, Dominique A, and Miossec, strings players Jean-François Assy, Frederic Dessus, Guillaume Fontanarosa, Bertrand Causse, Anne Causse Biragnet, Armelle Legoff, Frédéric Haffner, flute player Elliott, drummer Ludovic Morillon, and [[ondes Martenot]] player [[Christine Ott]].<ref name="am-lr">{{AllMusic|class=album|id=r781580|label=''Les Retrouvailles''}}</ref> ''Les Retrouvailles'' also includes a DVD short film entitled ''La Traversée'', directed by Aurélie du Boys, which documents the making of the album in Ushant, and incorporates an animated video for the non-album track "Le Train" and live versions of a handful of songs. The album produced a single, "Kala", sung by Elizabeth Fraser, and Tiersen also played piano on Staples' solo debut album, ''[[Lucky Dog Recordings 03-04]]''. The subsequent world tour of 2006 replaced the multi-instrumental ensemble with electric guitars and an ondes Martenot, and produced his third live album, ''[[On Tour (Yann Tiersen album)|On Tour]]'', which was released together with a DVD, directed by Aurélie du Boys, about the tour, in November 2006.<ref name="am-ot">{{AllMusic|class=album|id=r938647|label=''On Tour''}}</ref> In 2006, he also released two singles, "La Mancha" and "La Rade", and he was featured on ''The Endless Rise of the Sun'', the third studio album by electronic group Smooth, ''Raides à la ville'' extended play by Katel, and ''13m²'' by David Delabrosse.

After a five-year absence as a composer of film scores, Tiersen provided the [[Tabarly (soundtrack)|background music]] for ''[[Tabarly]]'',<ref name="am-t">{{AllMusic|class=album|id=r1392588|label=''Tabarly''}}</ref> a 2008 documentary film by Pierre Marcel about the French sailor, two-time champion of the [[Single-Handed Trans-Atlantic Race]], and father of French yachting [[Éric Tabarly]]. The documentary was released in June 2008, exactly ten years after Tabarly's death. Éric Tabarly was lost on the night of 12–13 June 1998 in the [[Irish Sea]] when he was struck by a [[gaff rig|gaff]] of his [[Pen Duick]] during heavy swell and knocked overboard from his yacht near [[Wales]] while on his way to the [[Fife]] [[Regatta]] in Scotland.  His body was recovered five weeks later off the coast of Ireland by a French [[fishing trawler]]. The documentary, narrated by Tabarly himself, traces his sporting career until his last meal in Ushant.<ref name="ATP-YT" /> Before the end of the decade, Tiersen also contributed to [[Christine Ott]]'s debut solo album ''[[Solitude Nomade]]'', and to Miossec's seventh studio album ''Finistériens''.

===''Dust Lane'' and ''Skyline'': 2010–present===
{{Main|Dust Lane (album)|l1=Dust Lane|Skyline (Yann Tiersen album)|l2=Skyline}}
{{Quote box
 |width   = 215px
 |align   = right
 |salign  = right
 |quote   = The name Dust Lane partly came from the image of the dirt road going into Gaza.
 |source  = —Yann Tiersen<ref name="MusicOMH-2010" />
}}
[[File:Yann Tiersen in concert, 2011.jpg|thumb|alt=A photo showing Elektronische Staubband [Lionel Laquerriere (on the left), and Yann Tiersen and Thomas Poli (on the right)] live in concert at Lazzaretto of Ancona, Italy, on 21 July 2011.|Elektronische Staubband [Lionel Laquerriere (left), and Yann Tiersen and Thomas Poli (right)] at [[Lazzaretto of Ancona]], Italy, 21 July 2011.]]
October 2010 saw the release of Tiersen's sixth studio album titled ''[[Dust Lane (album)|Dust Lane]]''. The album was two years in the making and was largely recorded in [[Ushant]], France.  Further parts were recorded in the [[Philippines]]. The album is preoccupied with mortality; during the recording sessions Tiersen lost his mother and a close friend. The recordings started out as simple song based tracks with Tiersen playing acoustic guitar, [[mandolin]] and [[bouzouki]].  New layers were added to the recordings creating a more complex sound. Then an array of vintage synthesisers and electric guitars were added to create further textures.<ref name="MusicOMH-2010">{{cite web |last=Randell |first=Edward |url=http://www.musicomh.com/features/interviews/interview-yann-tiersen |title=Interview: Yann Tiersen |work=Features |publisher=[[MusicOMH]] |year=2010 }}</ref><ref name="yt-dl">{{cite web|url=http://www.yanntiersen.com/dust-lane/ |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130210032605/http://www.yanntiersen.com/dust-lane/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=10 February 2013 |title=Dust Lane |publisher=Yann Tiersen Official Website }}</ref> The album was released by [[Mute Records]] in Europe and [[ANTI-]] Records in the US.<ref name="anti-dl">{{cite web |url=http://www.anti.com/releases/dust-lane/ |publisher=ANTI- |work=Catalog |title=Yann Tiersen, Dust Lane }}</ref><ref name="mute-dl">{{cite web |url=http://mute.com/release/yann-tiersen-dust-lane |publisher=Mute Records |work=Releases |title=Yann Tiersen • Dust Lane }}</ref><ref name="am-dl">{{AllMusic|class=album|id=r1963214|label=''Dust Lane''}}</ref> The record was promoted in a tour beginning in October 2010, starting in New York City. ''Dust Lane'' was preceded by the release of the vinyl EP ''PALESTINE'' and by the single for "Ashes". In 2010, Tiersen also contributed to the tribute album to cross-genre, experimental music group [[Coil (band)|Coil]] ''The Dark Age of Love'' by This Immortal Coil, a one-off tribute formation, and to ''[[Li(f)e]]'', the fourth solo studio album by hip-hop artist [[Sage Francis]].

October 2011 saw the European release of his seventh studio album, ''[[Skyline (Yann Tiersen album)|Skyline]]''. The nine-track album, a follow on from his ''Dust Lane'', was once again recorded at Tiersen's home on the island of Ushant in the south-western end of the [[English Channel]], with further parts recorded in Paris, San Francisco, Berlin, and [[Nashville]]. It was subsequently mixed by producer Ken Thomas in [[Leeds]], and mastered by [[Ray Staff]] in London.<ref name="ATP-YT">{{cite web |url=http://www.atpfestival.com/artist/yanntiersen.php |title=Yann Tiersen |publisher=All Tomorrow's Parties }}</ref><ref name="am-s">{{AllMusic |class=album |id=r2301618 |label=''Skyline'' |access-date=6 April 2012 }}</ref> The album produced the singles for "Monuments" and "I'm Gonna Live Anyhow". On 18 February 2012, Tiersen with Lionel Laquerriere, and Thomas Poli, presented his<!--??? theirs ???--> side project, Elektronische Staubband, at [[La Route du Rock]] music festival in [[Saint-Malo]]. It was about an hour of [[krautrock]], [[Electronic music|electronic]], and [[experimental music]] involving a dozen of synthesizers and [[Analog synthesizer|analog keyboards]] with the first three pieces of the set list taken from ''Dust Lane'' and the remaining five from ''Skyline''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.laroutedurock.com/elektronische-staubband/ |title=Elektronische Staubband (avec Yann Tiersen) (F) |language=fr |year=2012 |publisher=[[La Route du Rock]] |access-date=8 May 2012 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120606023839/http://www.laroutedurock.com/elektronische-staubband/ |archive-date=6 June 2012 }}</ref> Tiersen was also chosen by [[Jeff Mangum]] of [[Neutral Milk Hotel]] to perform at the [[All Tomorrow's Parties (music festival)|All Tomorrow's Parties]] festival in March 2012 in [[Minehead]], England.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.atpfestival.com/events/jeffmangum|title=ATP curated by Jeff Mangum (Neutral Milk Hotel)|website=All Tomorrow's Parties|access-date=18 March 2019}}</ref> ''Skyline'' was released in North America via ANTI- Records on 17 April 2012, and it was followed by the ''Skyline Tour'' with dates in the United States, Canada, [[Iceland]], Spain, [[Portugal]], France, [[Slovakia|Slovak Republic]], [[Austria]], [[Finland]] and the United Kingdom.

On 3 August 2016, it was announced that Tiersen married Emilie Quinquis in Ushant, Brittany.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.letelegramme.fr/finistere/ouessant-yann-tiersen-se-marie-en-breton-03-08-2016-11169068.php|title=Ouessant. Yann Tiersen se marie en breton|date=3 August 2016|website=Le Telegramme|access-date=18 March 2019}}</ref> Quinquis stated that she and Tiersen were married on 31 July 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/tinyfeetmusic/photos/a.241516335886954/1164818126890099/?type=3 |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/iarchive/facebook/239623436076244/1164818126890099 |archive-date=2022-02-26 |url-access=limited|title=TINY FEET|website=Facebook.com|access-date=18 March 2019}}{{cbignore}}</ref> Since 6 April 2017 they have a son.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/tinyfeetmusic/photos/a.241516335886954/1378864202152156/?type=3 |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/iarchive/facebook/239623436076244/1378864202152156 |archive-date=2022-02-26 |url-access=limited|title=TINY FEET|website=Facebook.com|access-date=18 March 2019}}{{cbignore}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/tinyfeetmusic/photos/a.241516335886954/1409368502435059/?type=3 |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/iarchive/facebook/239623436076244/1409368502435059 |archive-date=2022-02-26 |url-access=limited|title=TINY FEET|website=Facebook.com|access-date=18 March 2019}}{{cbignore}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tfRxQ4vdPrw&t=34m30s|title=Bali Breizh gant Émilie Quinquis/Tiny Feet|last=France 3 Bretagne|date=4 November 2017|access-date=18 March 2019|publisher=YouTube}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BhOzZInhQRP/ |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/iarchive/s/instagram/BhOzZInhQRP |archive-date=26 December 2021 |url-access=registration|title=TINY FEET on Instagram: "One year of poetry 😍"|website=Instagram.com|access-date=18 March 2019}}{{cbignore}}</ref>

==Music==
===Styles and instruments===
{{Quote box
 |width   = 234px
 |align   = right
 |salign  = right
 |quote   = [There is] no frontier between classical music and popular music, you are free to work with whatever you want. For me it’s natural to use lots of different instruments and textures and sounds and noises because life is like that.
 |source  = —Yann Tiersen<ref name="classicalmusicmagazine-yt">{{cite web|url=http://www.classicalmusicmagazine.org.uk/content/yann-tierson-music-sans-fronti%C3%A8res |title=Yann Tiers[e]n – Music Sans Frontières |date=2 April 2011 |publisher=Classical Music Magazine |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110405075031/http://www.classicalmusicmagazine.org.uk/content/yann-tierson-music-sans-fronti%C3%A8res |archive-date=5 April 2011 }}</ref>
}}
{{Quote box
 |width   = 234px
 |align   = right
 |salign  = right
 |quote   = I didn’t know French [[Bal-musette|musette music]] at all. Even people like [[Jacques Brel]] — I discovered Brel through [[Scott Walker (singer)|Scott Walker]]. My parents listened to Brel, of course, but when you’re a teenager you’re not interested. So it was only when I heard Scott Walker's versions that I thought "this is fucking good", you know. The only French singer I listened to was [[Serge Gainsbourg]].
 |source  = —Yann Tiersen<ref name="MusicOMH-2010" />
}}
Tiersen's music is influenced by the classical training he received as a child, by American and British [[punk subculture]], and by the music he used to listen to as a teenager. His musical style is deceptively easy to recognize but difficult to define. It varies greatly from one album to another and with time.  His melancholic music and composing techniques mix  classical and [[folk music]] elements with pop and rock ones. His delicate but deeply emotional style has been linked to [[Frédéric Chopin]] and the other great masters of [[Romantic music]], and also to [[Erik Satie]], the colourful figure of the early 20th century Parisian [[avant-garde]] whose work was a precursor to later artistic movements such as [[minimalism]], [[repetitive music]], and the [[Theatre of the Absurd]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gresham.ac.uk/lectures-and-events/erik-satie-his-music-the-vision-his-legacy |title=Erik Satie: His music, the vision, his legacy |date=16 April 2010 |location=Barnard's Inn Hall |publisher=Gresham College |work=Lectures and Events |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130102053914/http://www.gresham.ac.uk/lectures-and-events/erik-satie-his-music-the-vision-his-legacy |archive-date=2 January 2013 }}</ref> Tiersen is also compared to one of the most influential composers of the late 20th century, the American [[minimalism]], classical–[[Contemporary classical music|contemporary classical]], and [[ambient music]] composer [[Philip Glass]],<ref>{{Cite journal |journal=[[New York (magazine)|New York]] |url=http://nymag.com/news/features/influentials/16903/ |title=The Most Influential People in Classical and Dance |date=8 May 2006 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |title=The Guardian Profile: Philip Glass |url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2001/nov/24/arts.highereducation1 |date=24 November 2001 |first=John |last=O'Mahony |journal=[[The Guardian]] |location=London}}</ref> and to British minimalist music composer, pianist, [[libretto|librettist]] and [[musicologist]] [[Michael Nyman]], known for the many film [[soundtrack|scores]] he wrote during his lengthy career and who is the reason for Tiersen to be often called the Gallic Michael Nyman.<ref name="am-yt-bio" />

{{Quote box
 |width   = 234px
 |align   = right
 |salign  = right
 |quote   = I couldn’t play a brass instrument — I tried but I was really bad at it — I couldn’t play the flute, but the piano accordion was a keyboard so it was easy for me.
 |source  = —Yann Tiersen<ref name="MusicOMH-2010" />
}}
Tiersen started playing the piano and the violin at a young age.<ref name="e2" /> In 1983, at the age of thirteen, he broke his violin and bought an electric guitar. Tiersen only returned to his beginnings instrument years later, after searching for string sounds to [[Sampling (music)|sample]].<ref name="MusicOMH-2010" /> For his music albums, Tiersen composes and makes arrangements incorporating many instruments, including keyboards such as the piano, [[electric piano]], [[Rhodes piano|Fender Rhodes]], organs, [[harpsichord]], [[Bontempi]] and toy pianos, [[Korg]] and [[Moog synthesizer|Moog]] synthesizers, [[Mellotron]], piano accordions and [[melodica]], [[String instrument|string]]s as the violin, [[viola]], [[violone]] and the cello, different types of electric, acoustic or bass guitars, [[mandolin]], [[banjo]], [[ukulele]], [[bouzouki]] and [[oud]], [[brass instrument|brass]]es, like [[French horn|horn]]s, and woodwind instruments such as the saxophone, [[clarinet]], [[bassoon]], [[Pipe (instrument)|pipe]], [[oboe]] and the flute, percussions like drums, [[vibraphone]], [[marimba]], [[tubular bells]], [[Tom (instrument)|tom]], [[cymbal]], [[glockenspiel]] and [[Gong|tam-tam]], or the sounds produced by [[Leslie speaker]], [[music box]], [[carillon]]s, [[typewriter]]s, [[Cookware and bakeware|cooking vessel]]s, chairs, a [[Automobile|car]] or a [[bicycle wheel]]. Tiersen plays all of these instruments himself either in the studio or on a live set.<ref name="am-yt-bio" />

===Film scores===
Tiersen's ability to compose music that can be easily used for [[film score]]s was evident from the beginning. All tracks from his debut album, ''[[La Valse des monstres]]'', were conceived for stage adaptations and plays. The title track of his second album, ''[[Rue des cascades]]'', was used for ''[[The Dreamlife of Angels]]'' by [[Erick Zonca]],<ref name="festival-cannes.com" /><ref name="ac-1999" /> and several tracks from both albums plus three songs from ''[[Le Phare]]'' are featured on the soundtrack to [[Jean-Pierre Jeunet]]'s film ''[[Amélie]]''.<ref name="ATP-YT" /> Another track form ''Le Phare'', "L'Homme aux bras ballants", is the soundtrack to a short animation film by Laurent Gorgiard. Tiersen's pieces are also featured on ''[[Alice et Martin]]'' by [[André Téchiné]], and ''Qui plume la lune?'' by Christine Carrière.

Following the box-office success of ''Amélie'',<ref name="MusicOMH-2002" /><ref name="am-yt-bio" /> Tiersen's skills as a composer of film scores were much in demand, and this led him to compose the music for ''[[Good Bye, Lenin!]]'' by [[Wolfgang Becker (director, born 1954)|Wolfgang Becker]]. Although the soundtrack for ''Amélie'' consisted mainly of pieces that Tiersen had previously released on his first two albums, the soundtrack for ''Good Bye, Lenin!'' was conceived from scratch, except for "Comptine d'un autre été : L'après-midi", which is also featured on ''Amélie'''s soundtrack.<ref name="ATP-YT" />

Tiersen returned to making film soundtracks in 2008 after a years-long break, creating the score for a documentary about the sailor [[Éric Tabarly]].<ref name="ATP-YT" />

===Collaborations===
Tiersen has always composed his music in solitude, starting from simple melodies to which he added subsequent layers. His first album, ''[[La Valse des monstres]]'', is almost entirely performed by him alone playing all the instruments, with the exception of "Quimper 94" and "Le Banquet" with drums and [[Hi-hat (instrument)|charleston]] provided by Laurent Heudes.<ref name="am-lvdm" /> His second album, ''[[Rue des cascades]]'', saw the participation of French soloist singer [[Claire Pichet]], who provided vocals on two tracks on the album, "Rue des cascades" and "Naomi", and François-Xavier Schweyer, who played cello on "C'était ici" and "La Fenêtre".<ref name="am-rdc" /> ''[[Le Phare]]'' saw his first collaboration with French singer and songwriter [[Dominique A]]. Claire Pichet and drummer Sacha Toorop are also featured on this album,<ref name="am-lp" /> but both albums can be considered as a one-man works.

It is at this point in his career, around the end of the nineties, that his collaborations begin to grow. In 1997, he collaborated with French rock band [[Noir Désir]], the following year Tiersen and Dominique A released the single for "Monochrome",{{citation needed|date=November 2017}} and, in collaboration with French [[electronic rock]] band Bästard, the EP ''Bästard ~ Yann Tiersen'',{{citation needed|date=November 2017}} while 1999 saw the releases of ''[[Tout est calme]]'', a collaboration mini album by Yann Tiersen, The Married Monk, Claire Pichet, and Olivier Mellano,{{citation needed|date=November 2017}} and of his first live album, ''[[Black Session: Yann Tiersen]]''. The live album, recorded in December 1998, features Tiersen with Claire Pichet, Dominique A, [[The Divine Comedy (band)|The Divine Comedy]]'s singer and songwriter [[Neil Hannon]], Noir Désir's singer and songwriter [[Bertrand Cantat]], singer and illustrator [[Françoiz Breut]], anglophone French rock band The Married Monk, French folk rock group [[Têtes Raides]], the [[string quartet]] Quatuor à cordes, guitarist and composer Olivier Mellano, and author [[Mathieu Boogaerts]].{{citation needed|date=November 2017}} The soundtrack for ''[[Amélie]]'' saw for the first time the introduction of a full orchestra, the 35-member Ensemble Orchestral Synaxis, and of an [[ondes Martenot]] played by [[Christine Ott]].{{citation needed|date=November 2017}} Both will participate in the recording sessions for his next album, ''[[L'Absente]]'', which also includes American singer-songwriter and multi-instrumentalist [[Lisa Germano]], Belgian actress and singer [[Natacha Régnier]], Neil Hannon, and Têtes Raides, among others.<ref name="am-la" />

Tiersen's list of collaborators continues to grow. His second live album, ''[[C'était ici]]'', recorded during three concerts performed in February 2002 at the [[Cité de la Musique]] in Paris, features more than 50 musicians.<ref name="ma-cei" /> ''[[Yann Tiersen & Shannon Wright]]'', a collaboration album with American singer and songwriter [[Shannon Wright]], was released in October 2004,<ref name="am-ytasw">{{AllMusic|class=album|id=mw0000254936|label=''Yann Tiersen & Shannon Wright''|tab=credits}}</ref> and his 2005 album, ''[[Les Retrouvailles]]'', features vocals from [[Stuart Staples]] of [[Tindersticks]], English actress and singer [[Jane Birkin]], [[Breton people|Breton]] singer and songwriter [[Miossec]], [[Elizabeth Fraser]], the vocalist for the pioneer alternative rock group [[Cocteau Twins]], and the Orchestre National de Paris.<ref name="am-lr" /> The subsequent world tour produced his third live album ''[[On Tour (Yann Tiersen album)|On Tour]]'', which replaced the multi-instrumental ensemble of ''Les Retrouvailles'' with a more rock-oriented sound.<ref name="am-ot" /> The soundtrack to ''[[Tabarly (soundtrack)|Tabarly]]'' saw Tiersen return to [[minimalism]], in fact most of the compositions featured on the album are for solo piano.<ref name="am-t" /> But his two subsequent albums return to have a rock-oriented sound, with the only difference that ''[[Skyline (Yann Tiersen album)|Skyline]]'' has a higher number of contributors than ''[[Dust Lane]]''.<ref name="am-dl" /><ref name="am-s" />

Tiersen has contributed, either in part or in full, to the realization of several records among which stand out "[[Gin Soaked Boy]]" and ''[[Absent Friends (album)|Absent Friends]]'' by The Divine Comedy,<ref name="am-gsb">{{AllMusic|class=single|id=mr0000123103|label="Gin Soaked Boy"|tab=credits}}</ref><ref name="am-af">{{AllMusic|class=album|id=mw0000331570|label=''Absent Friends''|tab=credits}}</ref> ''[[Vingt à Trente Mille Jours]]'' by [[Françoiz Breut]],<ref name="am-vatmj">{{AllMusic|class=album|id=mw0000319823|label=''Vingt à Trente Mille Jours''|tab=credits}}</ref> ''[[Lucky Dog Recordings 03-04]]'' by [[Stuart A. Staples]],<ref name="am-ldr34">{{AllMusic|class=album|id=mw0000529279|label=''Lucky Dog Recordings 03-04''}}</ref> and ''[[Li(f)e]]'' by [[Sage Francis]],<ref name="am-l">{{AllMusic|class=album|id=mw0001977405|label=''Li(f)e''|tab=credits}}</ref> as well as records by Noir Désir,<ref name="am-erplj">{{AllMusic|class=album|id=mw0000804100|label=''En Route Pour La Joie ''|tab=credits}}</ref> Têtes Raides,{{citation needed|date=November 2017}} The Married Monk,<ref name="am-rocky">{{AllMusic|class=album|id=mw0000209217|label=''R/O/C/K/Y''|tab=credits}}</ref><ref name="am-tbk">{{AllMusic|class=album|id=mw0000655468|label=''The Belgian Kick''|tab=credits}}</ref> French electronic trio Smooth,<ref name="am-terots">{{AllMusic|class=album|id=mw0001472645|label=''The Endless Rise of the Sun''|tab=credits}}</ref> Katel, David Delabrosse,{{citation needed|date=November 2017}}  Christine Ott,{{citation needed|date=November 2017}} or Miossec.<ref name="am-f">{{AllMusic|class=album|id=mw0002053005|label=''Finistériens''}}</ref> In 2011, Tiersen, with Lionel Laquerriere and Thomas Poli, has also started Elektronische Staubband, a side project on [[electronic music]]. This new project is expected to lead to the release of a new album in 2013.

===Charity work===
In 2011, Tiersen collaborated with the [[Yellow Bird Project]] (YBP) to design a t-shirt,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.yellowbirdproject.com/products/yann-tiersen |title=Yellow Bird Project : Yann Tiersen Charity T-Shirt |website=www.yellowbirdproject.com |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111001124039/http://www.yellowbirdproject.com/products/yann-tiersen |archive-date=2011-10-01}} </ref> which was sold to raise money for [[Médecins Sans Frontières]] (MSF). The main reason he chose to support MSF, is for their work as one of the three charities helping refugees in Libya at the time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yanntiersen.fr/2011/09/charity-tshirt-at-yellow-bird/|archive-url=https://archive.today/20130917112205/http://www.yanntiersen.fr/2011/09/charity-tshirt-at-yellow-bird/|url-status=dead|title=Charity Tshirt at Yellow Bird – Yann Tiersen|date=17 September 2013|archive-date=17 September 2013|website=Archive.is|access-date=18 March 2019}}</ref> A live video session was also filmed in the MSF London offices to promote the T-shirt and raise awareness for the cause.<ref>{{cite news
  | last = Gibson
  | first = Dan
  | title = Let's Watch a Yann Tiersen Video and Buy His T-Shirt
  | publisher = Tucson Weekly
  | date = 27 March 2012
  | url = http://www.tucsonweekly.com/TheRange/archives/2012/03/27/lets-watch-a-yann-tiersen-video-and-buy-his-t-shirt
  | access-date = 17 September 2013 }}</ref>

===Contributions===
* ''[[One Trip/One Noise]]'' (by [[Noir Désir]]) (1998)
** "À ton étoile" (arrangements, strings, vibraphone, bell, mandolin, electric guitar and bass)
* "[[Gin Soaked Boy]]" (by The Divine Comedy) (1999)
* ''[[Vingt à Trente Mille Jours]]'' (by [[Françoiz Breut]]) (2000)
** "Porsmouth" (vibraphone), "Vingt à trente mille jours" (vibraphone), "L'heure bleue" (violin), "Le verre pilé" (vibraphone); arrangements
* ''[[Gratte-poil]]'' (by [[Têtes Raides]]) (2000)
** "Cabaret des nues" (violin)
* ''R/O/C/K/Y'' (by [[The Married Monk]]) (2001)
** "Roma Amor" (strings, vibraphone), "Holidays" (strings), and "Cyro's Request" (vibraphone)
* ''[[Les oiseaux de passage]]'' (tribute to [[Georges Brassens]]) (2001)
** cover of "Le parapluie" with Natacha Régnier
* ''[[Absent Friends (album)|Absent Friends]]'' (by [[The Divine Comedy (band)|The Divine Comedy]]) (2004)
** "Sticks & Stones" (accordion); "Anthem for Bored Youth" (accordion), a track appearing only on the French limited edition
* ''The Belgian Kick'' (by The Married Monk) (2004)
** viola on "Love Commander" and "Totally Confused"
* ''[[Lucky Dog Recordings 03-04]]'' (by [[Stuart A. Staples]]) (2005)
** "She Don't Have to Be Good to Me" (piano)
* ''[[The Endless Rise of the Sun]]'' (by Smooth) (2006)
** "The Endless Rise of the Sun" (keyboards)
* ''[[Raides à la ville]]'' (by Katel) (2006)
** "La Vielle" (violin)
* ''[[13m²]]'' (by David Delabrosse) (2006)
** production and arrangements
* ''[[Solitude Nomade]]'' (by [[Christine Ott]]) (2009)
** "Pensées sauvages" (violin)
* ''[[Finistériens]]'' (by [[Miossec]]) (2009)
** music and arrangements
* ''[[Li(f)e]]'' (by [[Sage Francis]]) (2010)
** production and arrangements on "The Best of Times"
* ''[[Soyons désinvoltes, n'ayons l'air de rien]]'' (2×CD+DVD Deluxe edition) (by [[Noir Désir]]) (2011)
** "À ton étoile (Yann Tiersen Mix)" (arrangements, strings, vibraphone, carillon, mandolin, bass, and electric guitar)
